texts.shortText: A ‘textbook’ hydroid and the species is often depicted in general accounts of the group. Creeping filaments attached to the surfaces of algae or other hard substrata give rise to elongate, feather-like vertical stems which each bear branches alternately to the left and right. The zooids emerge from only the upper side of these branches and each is protected within a smooth, goblet-like cup (the hydrotheca) and is flanked by two tiny protective individuals (nematothecae - visible only microscopically). Reproductive individuals are borne close to the main stem and are flask-shaped with a smooth, slightly-curved neck. Colony colour cream.
Vertical stems typically 30 mm tall, but can be up to 60 mm.

Global: Very widely distributed, including Europe and Mediterranean, Gulf of Mexico, both coasts of South America, Southern Africa, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal and mostly shallow water, but recorded down to 430 m depth.

Extremely common fouling species on algae, other sedentary invertebrates (such as ascidians and sponges), rocks and artificial structures. Often in expansive colonies covering areas of the substratum.
Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.

Colonies expand by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of stems. Male and female polyps occur on the same colony. There is no medusa stage and sperm enter the female polyp and fertilise the eggs. Planula larvae are subsequently released into the plankton and settle to form new colonies.

Widespread and common, but in reality, there are some 12 regional species in this genus that can be difficult to separate without detailed microscopic examination. Also there are similar species in other genera, for example the very common Fine feather-hydroid Kirchenpauria pinnata is similar in overall appearance, but lacks nematothecae and the gonothecae have lateral ridges and a spiky apex.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 24, 29).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 399).
